articles.headline: A Loophole Big Enough to Lose a Billion
articles.snippet: For years, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has allowed firms to use an “alternative” calculation of customer assets that vastly understates what firms actually owe.
articles.abstract: For years, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has allowed firms to use an “alternative” calculation of customer assets that vastly understates what firms actually owe.
articles.lead_paragraph: If nothing else, the collapse of MF Global has made one thing clear: The notion that customer assets were safe was a sham.

articles.headline: Cardinal’s Aide Is Found Guilty in Abuse Case
articles.snippet: Msgr. William J. Lynn became the first senior Roman Catholic official in the United States to be convicted for covering up child sexual abuses by priests in his charge.
articles.abstract: Msgr. William J. Lynn became the first senior Roman Catholic official in the United States to be convicted for covering up child sexual abuses by priests in his charge.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Msgr. William J. Lynn, a former cardinal’s aide, was found guilty Friday of endangering children, becoming the first senior official of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States convicted of covering up sexual abuses by priests under his supervision.
articles.byline: By Jon Hurdle and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: American and Pilots Near Accord on Contract
articles.snippet: The pact would give the airline more flexible work rules and the ability to use regional partners to fly larger jets, which had been a hurdle in previous talks.
articles.abstract: The pact would give the airline more flexible work rules and the ability to use regional partners to fly larger jets, which had been a hurdle in previous talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Airlines and the union representing its pilots are close to reaching a deal on a new contract, a significant milestone in the ailing carrier’s seven-month-old bankruptcy, although one that still leaves the door open for a possible merger with US Airways.

articles.headline: Getting Lost in the Labyrinth of Medical Bills
articles.snippet: How do hospitals and doctors arrive at the fees they charge? The not-so-simple answer is that it depends on the medical provider and the insurance company, and what sort of deal the provider has negotiated with their insurer.
articles.abstract: How do hospitals and doctors arrive at the fees they charge? The not-so-simple answer is that it depends on the medical provider and the insurance company, and what sort of deal the provider has negotiated with their insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ask Jean Poole, a medical billing advocate, about her work helping people navigate the bewildering world of medical bills and insurance claims, and the stories pour out. There’s the client who was billed almost $11,000 for an 11-minute hand surgery.  The cancer patient who was charged $9,550.40 for a round of chemotherapy he never received.

articles.headline: An Increase in Barriers to Trade Is Reported
articles.snippet: Trade experts say that governments have felt pressure to protect their domestic industries and started inhibiting foreign competition to compensate.
articles.abstract: Trade experts say that governments have felt pressure to protect their domestic industries and started inhibiting foreign competition to compensate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Argentina tweaked import regulations on bottle caps and water balloons. India banned exports of cotton. South Africa instituted a tariff on artificial turf. Those recent policy changes sound minute. But they, and scores more like them, have stoked fears about trade protectionism rising as the global economy cools.

articles.headline: A Sober New Reality in Credit Downgrades for Banks
articles.snippet: Banking industry analysts think downgrades by Moody’s will cause lasting pain for some of the biggest American banks.
articles.abstract: Banking industry analysts think downgrades by Moody’s will cause lasting pain for some of the biggest American banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a consumer’s credit score drops, it is hard to recover financially. Wall Street firms could face the same fate.

articles.headline: Killings Curb Reporting of Mexican Crime Wave
articles.snippet: The recent death of Víctor Báez, a longstanding police reporter, has added to a climate of fear among journalists in Veracruz State, a center of increasing drug violence.
articles.abstract: The recent death of Víctor Báez, a longstanding police reporter, has added to a climate of fear among journalists in Veracruz State, a center of increasing drug violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: XALAPA, Mexico — Throwing his burly frame to the ground, the photojournalist Alberto Morales click, click, clicked away on Tuesday as police officers and soldiers in body armor barked into radios, hoisted their rifles and crouched into position on word of a suspicious vehicle moving in.

articles.headline: Companies’ Ills Did Not Harm Romney’s Firm
articles.snippet: Bain Capital, the private equity firm co-founded by Mitt Romney, structured its deals so that it was hard for the firm to ever really lose, even if the companies it owned foundered.
articles.abstract: Bain Capital, the private equity firm co-founded by Mitt Romney, structured its deals so that it was hard for the firm to ever really lose, even if the companies it owned foundered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cambridge Industries, an automotive plastics supplier whose losses had been building for three consecutive years, finally filed for bankruptcy in May 2000 under a mountain of debt that had ballooned to more than $300 million.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Chinese Data Mask Depth of Slowdown, Executives Say
articles.snippet: Corporate executives and economists say officials in some Chinese cities and provinces are falsifying statistics to mask the extent of the downturn in the nation’s economy.
articles.abstract: Corporate executives and economists say officials in some Chinese cities and provinces are falsifying statistics to mask the extent of the downturn in the nation’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As the Chinese economy continues to sputter, prominent corporate executives in China and Western economists say there is evidence that local and provincial officials are falsifying economic statistics to disguise the true depth of the troubles.

articles.headline: A Debate Goes Behind Closed Doors
articles.snippet: A proposal takes aim at sending derivatives trading overseas to escape the eyes of American regulators, but at the C.F.T.C. commissioners are said to be planning to cast their votes in private.
articles.abstract: A proposal takes aim at sending derivatives trading overseas to escape the eyes of American regulators, but at the C.F.T.C. commissioners are said to be planning to cast their votes in private.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the long war over Wall Street regulation, a little-noticed clash erupted this week over a plan to rein in risky trading overseas.

articles.headline: Apple’s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay
articles.snippet: While consumers tend to think of Apple’s headquarters as the company’s heart and soul, a majority of its workers in the United States are hourly wage earners selling iPhones and MacBooks.
articles.abstract: While consumers tend to think of Apple’s headquarters as the company’s heart and soul, a majority of its workers in the United States are hourly wage earners selling iPhones and MacBooks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, during his best three-month stretch, Jordan Golson sold about $750,000 worth of computers and gadgets at the Apple Store in Salem, N.H. It was a performance that might have called for a bottle of Champagne — if that were a luxury Mr. Golson could have afforded.

articles.headline: A Georgia Town Takes the People’s Business Private
articles.snippet: Cities across the United States have dabbled for years with various levels of privatization, but few have taken the idea as far as Sandy Springs, Ga.
articles.abstract: Cities across the United States have dabbled for years with various levels of privatization, but few have taken the idea as far as Sandy Springs, Ga.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANDY SPRINGS, Ga.

articles.headline: Suggested Safeguards Irk Fund Industry
articles.snippet: Objections to proposals on money market mutual funds, intended to avert a future taxpayer bailout, echo past battles over financial industry reforms.
articles.abstract: Objections to proposals on money market mutual funds, intended to avert a future taxpayer bailout, echo past battles over financial industry reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR a moment last week, watching the Senate Banking Committee hearings on money market mutual fund reforms, I thought I had fallen into a time warp. As Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, outlined proposals meant to ensure that taxpayers would never need to bail out a money fund, some of the sharp questioning she received had a depressingly familiar ring.

articles.headline: Helpful Hands on Life’s Last Segregated Journey
articles.snippet: When a black person dies in one of the rural counties around Madison, Ga., chances are the body will end up in the hands of Charles Menendez.
articles.abstract: When a black person dies in one of the rural counties around Madison, Ga., chances are the body will end up in the hands of Charles Menendez.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Ga. — When a black person dies in one of the rural counties around here, chances are the body will end up in the hands of Charles Menendez.

articles.headline: Supporters Slow to Grasp Health Law’s Legal Risks
articles.snippet: Early confidence in the law’s constitutionality, based on Supreme Court precedents, proved to be a miscalculation that put the White House on the defensive as its legal strategy evolved over the last two years.
articles.abstract: Early confidence in the law’s constitutionality, based on Supreme Court precedents, proved to be a miscalculation that put the White House on the defensive as its legal strategy evolved over the last two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Supreme Court likely to render judgment on President Obama’s health care law this week, the White House and Congress find themselves in a position that many advocates of the legislation once considered almost unimaginable.

articles.headline: For Wealthy Romney Donors, Up Close and Personal Access
articles.snippet: The campaign offered an extraordinary level of access to Mitt Romney at a three-day retreat that even seasoned political contributors said dwarfed previous presidential powwows.
articles.abstract: The campaign offered an extraordinary level of access to Mitt Romney at a three-day retreat that even seasoned political contributors said dwarfed previous presidential powwows.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah —They schmoozed with Mitt Romney at a barbecue cookout at the Olympic Park, pressing him on labor regulations and the threat of a nuclear Iran as downhill skiers performed midair flips behind them.

articles.headline: Libya Democracy Clashes With Fervor for Jihad
articles.snippet: Two jihadis in Libya represent opposing directions for Islamists, democracy or militancy with Taliban-style rule, and for the moment, democracy appears to have the upper hand.
articles.abstract: Two jihadis in Libya represent opposing directions for Islamists, democracy or militancy with Taliban-style rule, and for the moment, democracy appears to have the upper hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARNAH, Libya — Abdul-Hakim al-Hasadi first took up arms nearly 20 years ago to try to bring Islamic law to Libya. He studied under the Taliban in Afghanistan, and during last year’s uprising he led a local militia council here in a city famous as a cradle of Islamic jihad.

articles.headline: Named Egypt’s Winner, Islamist Makes History
articles.snippet: Mohamed Morsi’s recognition as president handed the Muslim Brotherhood a new weapon in its struggle for power with Egypt’s ruling military council.
articles.abstract: Mohamed Morsi’s recognition as president handed the Muslim Brotherhood a new weapon in its struggle for power with Egypt’s ruling military council.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers on Sunday officially recognized Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, handing the Islamists both a symbolic triumph and a potent weapon in their struggle for power against the country’s top generals.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Manager to Pay $405 Million in Madoff Settlement
articles.snippet: J. Ezra Merkin, whose funds lost about $1.2 billion when Mr. Madoff’s fraud collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $405 million over three years to compensate his investors.
articles.abstract: J. Ezra Merkin, whose funds lost about $1.2 billion when Mr. Madoff’s fraud collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $405 million over three years to compensate his investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clients of J. Ezra Merkin, a prominent Wall Street hedge fund manager who invested his clients’ money in Bernard L. Madoff’s epic Ponzi scheme, will recover more than $400 million under a civil settlement negotiated by the New York State attorney general’s office.

articles.headline: With Tablet, Microsoft Takes Aim at Hardware Missteps
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s plan to create its own tablet is the most striking evidence yet of the friction with its partners on the hardware side of the PC business.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s plan to create its own tablet is the most striking evidence yet of the friction with its partners on the hardware side of the PC business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Around the time the iPad came out more than two years ago, Microsoft executives got an eye-opening jolt about how far Apple would go to gain an edge for its products.

articles.headline: Pressure for Action at Brussels Meeting
articles.snippet: As central bankers and foreign leaders push for a more unified Euro zone banking system, little has changed in the positions of the four European Union leaders that would need to agree on a plan.
articles.abstract: As central bankers and foreign leaders push for a more unified Euro zone banking system, little has changed in the positions of the four European Union leaders that would need to agree on a plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — If the past is any guide, European Union leaders will leave their summit meeting this week waving promises to weave the euro zone more tightly together. They are likely to back a plan to finance infrastructure projects in stricken countries.

articles.headline: HBO’s ‘Newsroom’ as a Map for CNN
articles.snippet: CNN’s tenuous plight as the honest tradesman of the TV news business is reflected in the scripts of “The Newsroom,” Aaron Sorkin’s latest show.
articles.abstract: CNN’s tenuous plight as the honest tradesman of the TV news business is reflected in the scripts of “The Newsroom,” Aaron Sorkin’s latest show.
articles.lead_paragraph: CNN, which has long struggled to locate an anchor for its 8 p.m. hour, may have finally found him.

articles.headline: NBC Series Saved by Delayed Viewership
articles.snippet: “Smash,” an NBC drama, was considered a flop, but it is considered a ratings success among viewers 18 to 49 because of devices like digital video recorders.
articles.abstract: “Smash,” an NBC drama, was considered a flop, but it is considered a ratings success among viewers 18 to 49 because of devices like digital video recorders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The narrative about the new NBC drama “Smash” this spring, promulgated largely by critics and bloggers, centered on the show’s serial failings: it did not live up to its pilot; it alienated viewers with sappy writing and acting; and the only reason NBC ordered a second season was because Bob Greenblatt, the top NBC entertainment executive, decided its fate based on his heart, not his head.

articles.headline: New Rules on Public Pension Funds Seek Better Disclosure
articles.snippet: The new rules from the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, intended to make it tougher for governments to hide shortfalls, could lead to credit downgrades and higher borrowing costs.
articles.abstract: The new rules from the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, intended to make it tougher for governments to hide shortfalls, could lead to credit downgrades and higher borrowing costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cities, states and the millions of Americans who work for them will soon face new accounting rules that will require many local governments to disclose pension obligations that were hidden until now, stepping up the pressure to rein in public workers’ benefits.

articles.headline: Seeing an Obama Army in Gay Pride Legions
articles.snippet: Campaign officials said annual marches and festivals were their best chance yet to convert enthusiasm among gays and lesbians for President Obama into more than just votes.
articles.abstract: Campaign officials said annual marches and festivals were their best chance yet to convert enthusiasm among gays and lesbians for President Obama into more than just votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: To most passers-by, the tens of thousands of people who jammed the sidewalks of Greenwich Village on Sunday were just the typical tank-top-clad revelers of a gay pride weekend.

articles.headline: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling
articles.snippet: The impending decision by the Supreme Court on President Obama’s health care law will be the beginning of the end of one of the most divisive policy battles in decades.
articles.abstract: The impending decision by the Supreme Court on President Obama’s health care law will be the beginning of the end of one of the most divisive policy battles in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers are not usually eager to get back to Washington after a weekend in their districts, especially during campaign season. But Representative Michele Bachmann boarded a flight from Minnesota on Sunday night — even though the House will not meet until Tuesday — to make sure she would not miss the Washington moment she has been excitedly anticipating, the Supreme Court ruling on President Obama’s health care law.

articles.headline: Your Ad Here, on a Fire Truck? Broke Cities Sell Naming Rights
articles.snippet: Many governmental entities across the nation are looking at new money-raising strategies to keep from cutting services.
articles.abstract: Many governmental entities across the nation are looking at new money-raising strategies to keep from cutting services.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Should this city’s red fire trucks be transformed into rolling billboards?

articles.headline: In Documents on Pain Drug, Signs of Doubt and Deception
articles.snippet: Documents in a fraud case against Pfizer suggest that research officials were less than forthcoming about the safety of the arthritis drug Celebrex during an early trial study.
articles.abstract: Documents in a fraud case against Pfizer suggest that research officials were less than forthcoming about the safety of the arthritis drug Celebrex during an early trial study.
articles.lead_paragraph: A research director for Pfizer was positively buoyant after reading that an important medical conference had just featured a study claiming that the new arthritis drug Celebrex was safer on the stomach than more established drugs.

articles.headline: Blocking Parts of Arizona Law, Justices Allow Its Centerpiece
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court rejected much of Arizona’s immigration law but permitted the state’s instruction to its police to check the immigration status of people they detain.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court rejected much of Arizona’s immigration law but permitted the state’s instruction to its police to check the immigration status of people they detain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday delivered a split decision on Arizona’s tough 2010 immigration law, upholding its most hotly debated provision but blocking others on the grounds that they interfered with the federal government’s role in setting immigration policy.
